channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: EgyptAir Plane Disappears Over Mediterranean, Airline Says
item.description: The airline said the plane had been traveling at an altitude of 37,000 feet and was carrying 56 passengers and 10 crew members.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Benjamin Netanyahu Seeks Ultranationalists for Coalition in Israel
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, right, with Avigdor Lieberman, a former foreign minister, at a Likud-Yisrael Beiteinu campaign rally in Ashdod, Israel in 2013.
item.description: The prime minister, whose talks with the Zionist Union broke down, has offered to name Avigdor Lieberman, leader of the Yisrael Beiteinu party, defense minister.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: An Ayatollah’s Daughter Prompts a Debate on Religious Persecution in Iran
item.media:description: Faezeh Hashemi, center, in 2009. A visit by Ms. Hashemi, a daughter of a prominent ayatollah, to Fariba Kamalabadi, a leader in the Bahai faith, highlighted the harsh treatment of the group. Ms. Hashemi became acquainted with Ms. Kamalabadi in 2013, when they shared a prison cell.
item.description: A visit by Faezeh Hashemi, a daughter of the former president of Iran, to the home of Fariba Kamalabadi, a Bahai leader, highlighted the harsh treatment of the group.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Victims of Boko Haram, and Now Shunned by Their Communities
item.media:description: An Islamic naming ceremony celebrating the birth of a child at the camp for displaced people on the outskirts of Maiduguri, Nigeria, in April.
item.media:credit: Ashley Gilbertson for The New York Times
item.description: Nigerians who return from captivity after being kidnapped and raped by Boko Haram are met with suspicion that they have joined the militants’ ranks.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: Nigerian Girl Abducted by Boko Haram From Chibok Is Found
item.media:description: This photograph released by the Nigerian military on Wednesday shows a girl it says is Amina Ali, who was one of the schoolgirls kidnapped by Boko Haram in Chibok two years ago. Ms. Ali, who was found Wednesday, has a 4-month-old baby girl named Safiya.
item.description: The girl was wandering in the forest Tuesday when a vigilante group lying in wait to ambush a Boko Haram camp came across her, a commander said.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS STEIN and DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: Brazil’s Abortion Restrictions Compound Challenge of Zika Virus
item.description: Abortion is almost always a crime in Brazil, punishable by up to three years in jail, and there is no exception for defects caused by the Zika virus.
item.dc:creator: BRENT McDONALD

item.title: Ecuador Rattled by Two Powerful Earthquakes
item.media:description: People in Manta, Ecuador, left their homes and waited on the streets after an earthquake struck early Wednesday.
item.description: The quakes, magnitudes 6.7 and 6.8, struck a month after the worst temblor to hit the country in decades killed more than 650 people and injured more than 16,600.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Floods and Landslides in Sri Lanka Leave Dozens Dead
item.media:description: Survivors of the landslide in the Aranyake region of Sri Lanka on Wednesday.
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of people were also displaced, and officials said that the death toll was likely to rise.
item.dc:creator: DHARISHA BASTIANS

item.title: China and India Burdened by Untreated Mental Disorders
item.media:description: Patients receiving brainwave therapy at a hospital specializing in mental health care in Quzhou in China’s Zhejiang Province in October 2013.
item.description: Less than 10 percent of people receive effective treatment in the two countries, a report has found, and the burden of disability is higher than in all Western countries combined.
item.dc:creator: BENEDICT CAREY

item.title: China Finds Its Global Ambitions Humbled in Its Own Backyard
item.media:description: A pro-democracy demonstration in Hong Kong on Wednesday during a visit by a high-ranking Chinese official, Zhang Dejiang.
item.media:credit: Dale De La Rey/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Pro-democracy demonstrators protest a Chinese official visiting Hong Kong, while Taiwan prepares to inaugurate a president wary of Beijing’s influence.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE and AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: German Comic to Fight Ruling on Poem Insulting Turkish Leader
item.media:description: Jan Böhmermann.
item.description: A lawyer for Jan Böhmermann, who wrote a satirical verse about the Turkish president, said his client rejected a court ruling that bars him from repeating the whole poem.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: U.S. Returns a Stolen Christopher Columbus Letter, but Mystery Remains
item.media:description: An image of the stolen letter, which was written by Christopher Columbus in 1493. It was returned to Italy on Wednesday.
item.description: The 1493 letter was taken from a library in Florence, and eventually ended up as a donation to the Library of Congress. It was returned to Italy on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Chinese Aircraft Flies Within 50 Feet of U.S. Surveillance Plane in South China Sea
item.description: The encounter on Tuesday over the South China Sea is the latest sign of growing tensions over China’s territorial claims and tactics in the waterway.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Justin Trudeau Elbows Lawmaker in Parliamentary Quarrel in Canada
item.description: The prime minister apologized for the altercation in the House of Commons, which the opposition called “pathetic” and “deeply traumatic.”
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Reza Zarrab, Charged With Violating Sanctions on Iran, Seeks Bail Deal
item.media:description: Reza Zarrab in 2013.
item.description: Mr. Zarrab, a businessman with ties to Turkey’s president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, is seeking release from a Manhattan jail on a $50 million bond with strict conditions.
item.dc:creator: BENJAMIN WEISER

item.title: Yukio Ninagawa, 80, Who Directed Avant-Garde Productions of Classics, Dies
item.media:description: Yukio Ninagawa, left, in 2013, in Japan.
item.media:credit: The Asahi Shimbun, via Getty Images
item.description: Mr. Ninagawa fused Kabuki with Western realism to mount original versions of Greek and Shakespearean tragedies in Japan, Europe and the United States.
item.dc:creator: SAM ROBERTS
item.category: A Thousand Knives, a Thousand Eyes (Book)

item.title: Fort McMurray Residents May Be Allowed Back Even as Fire Rages
item.media:description: An aerial view of the devastation caused by the wildfire in Fort McMurray, Alberta.
item.description: The return of residents evacuated on May 3 is contingent on the restoration of a variety of basic services, Alberta’s premier said.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Letter From China: Apple Case Underscores Pitfalls of Doing Business in China
item.media:description: Some of Xintong Tiandi’s IPHONE leather goods.
item.description: Tracking the dispute between Apple and a Chinese leather goods company using the iPhone trademark can be a frustrating journey through a maze.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: U.N. AIDS Meeting Faces Dispute Over 22 Barred Groups
item.media:description: H.I.V. testing provided by Unaids workers last year in Algiers, the capital of Algeria.
item.description: A number of countries have blocked groups that represent the rights of gays, transgender people and drug users.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Kerry Meets Egypt’s Leader, and Where Are Reporters? Corralled at the Airport
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry, left, with President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt at the presidential palace in Cairo on Wednesday.
item.description: Diplomats often disappear behind closed doors. But not even being allowed to see the doors close sets something of a new standard.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: A Danger for Doctors in China: Patients’ Angry Relatives
item.description: A doctor who died after being struck on the head, apparently by family members of a patient, became the latest medical worker attacked in China.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: French Plan for Middle East Peace Talks Hits a Familiar Snag
item.media:description: The French foreign minister, Jean-Marc Ayrault, front left, met with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, front right, on Sunday in Jerusalem.
item.description: A French initiative to move beyond the current stalemate between the Israelis and Palestinians has already been complicated by competing interests.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Japanese Olympic Committee to Investigate Awarding of 2020 Games to Tokyo
item.media:description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan, third from right, and Tokyo delegation members in 2013 after the city won the bid to host the 2020 Summer Games.
item.description: The committee’s chief said a commission would be looking into payments made to a Singapore company called Black Tidings.
item.dc:creator: DAVID JOLLY

item.title: When Cultural Heritage Is Caught in the Cross Hairs
item.media:description: Tourists at the Parthenon in Athens in January 2015.
item.media:credit: Eirini Vourloumis for The New York Times
item.description: Palmyra, Syria, has been liberated, but Russia has put a military base there. Palmyra is the latest of many examples of cultural sites militarized or damaged in wartime.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER and SEWELL CHAN
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: W.H.O. Cites Low to Moderate Risk of Zika’s Imminent Spread to Europe
item.media:description: Aedes aegypti mosquitoes. The World Health Organization that said 18 European countries, mostly concentrated around the Mediterranean, faced a moderate risk of local outbreaks of the mosquito-borne Zika virus if no action was taken to address the threat.
item.description: An assessment identified three areas — in Georgia, Russia and on the Portuguese island of Madeira — that are most vulnerable to a breakout.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Reporter's Notebook: Yemen’s War Becomes the Mother of Reinvention
item.media:description: Solar panels on display at an alternative-energy fair in Sana, Yemen, in February.
item.description: Saddled for decades with feckless leaders and now in the midst of a civil conflict, Yemenis have been forced to adapt.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Sinosphere: A Subversive Message in Hong Kong Goes Up in Lights
item.description: Numbers displayed on the city’s tallest building count down the seconds until a framework that guarantees civil liberties for the former British colony will expire.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN

item.title: Sinosphere: Panda Alive and Well, Taiwan Says, Despite Chinese Reports to Contrary
item.media:description: A photo of Tuan Tuan released by the Taipei Zoo on Monday included copies of the day’s newspapers.
item.description: Some saw it as a bad sign for China-Taiwan relations when Tuan Tuan, a giant panda sent to the island in 2008, was reported dead. But it wasn’t so.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Suzuki Reports Improper Fuel Economy Tests, but Denies Cheating
item.description: The Japanese automaker said its methods did not exaggerate results. Also Wednesday, the chief of Mitsubishi said he would resign after a fuel-test scandal there.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE

item.title: What in the World: A British Town Weighs Its Officials’ Merits, With Scales
item.media:credit: Illustration by Cari Vander Yacht; Photos by Claudio Divizia/Shutterstock
item.description: Tradition equates getting fat in office with fiscal imprudence or worse, so once a year, politicians have to mount the scales in public.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: What in the World: In Finland, a Postal Worker Will Mow Your Lawn
item.media:description: Neither snow nor rain nor heat nor untidy grass will stop Finnish couriers.
item.media:credit: Illustration by Tamara Shopsin; Photos by Charles Brutlag, Mega Pixel, Claudio Divizia/Shutterstock
item.description: Stamp sales have slumped in the digital era, so postal services are trying new ways to earn revenue — some of them far afield from carrying the mail.
item.dc:creator: JAKE DOHERTY

item.title: What in the World: The Mountain That Tops Everest (Because the Earth Is Fat)
item.media:description: Earth flattens at its poles and bulges slightly around its waistline, making its radius about 13 miles greater at the Equator.
item.description: Mount Chimborazo in Ecuador rises about 20,500 feet above sea level, far short of Everest’s 29,029 feet. But it’s a different story when you measure from the center of the Earth.
item.dc:creator: ELI ROSENBERG

item.title: Sinosphere: Skeptics Jeer After Chinese Couple Bring Party Into the Bridal Suite
item.description: The story, with photos, of a couple spending their wedding night copying the Communist Party Constitution by hand was met with scoffs on social media.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Austria’s Election Is a Warning to the West
item.media:description: Norbert Hofer, center, of the Austrian Freedom Party, took 35 percent of the vote in the first round of the presidential election.
item.description: For the first time since the defeat of Nazism, a Western European country might elect a far-right head of state.
item.dc:creator: SYLVIE KAUFFMANN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: How I Survived Four and a Half Years in Captivity
item.description: My Islamist kidnappers tried to break my spirit. But even in the mountains of Afghanistan I found strength.
item.dc:creator: SHAHBAZ TASEER

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Can Boko Haram Be Defeated?
item.media:description: A Nigerian soldier at a base in Lagos as part of a military operation against Boko Haram.
item.description: Nigeria’s president claims the jihadist group has been beaten. In reality, it’s just evolved.
item.dc:creator: MAX SIOLLUN

item.title: Mao and Me: A Beijing Correspondent Reflects
item.media:description: Mao's portrait hangs in many cars in China, a talisman against accidents. This one hangs in the car of Chen Lei, a driver for a Russian bank. Taken in Beijing on May 18. 2016.
item.description: On the 50th anniversary of the Cultural Revolution, Didi Kirsten Tatlow knows she’s not the only person in China who’s dreaming about the Chairman.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN

item.title: On the Ground in Aleppo: Bloodshed, Misery and Hope
item.media:description: A civilian evacuated a baby on Friday from a site that had been hit by airstrikes in a rebel-controlled area of Aleppo, Syria. Inhabitants of the city carry on with work and school despite fighting that has killed more than 200 civilians in the past week.
item.description: The New York Times’s Cairo bureau chief reported from Aleppo, Syria, where inhabitants try to carry on despite a civil war’s inescapable reality.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: How ISIS Built the Machinery of Terror Under Europe’s Gaze
item.media:description: The Paris attacks left 130 dead in November, but a branch within the Islamic State was obsessed with striking Europe at least two years before then.
item.description: Two years before the Paris and Brussels assaults, a special branch of the group was churning out smaller attacks that the authorities repeatedly discounted as isolated or random acts.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
